    Rmarkdown & bootstraplib

    Carson Sievert

    2020-01-16

    rmarkdown.Rmd

    Bootstrap 4

    NOTE: This functionality currently requires installing an experimental branch of rmarkdown: remotes::install_github('rstudio/rmarkdown#1706').

    To use Bootstrap 4 in rmarkdown, use the bootstrap_version parameter to the html_document output format. In addition to this “strict” Bootstrap 4 mode, there is “compatible” Bootstrap 4 mode (i.e., bootstrap_version: 4-3), which allows you to rely on BS3 style nav/navbar markup. Only use this compatibility mode if you have existing html_document/html_document_base output formats that rely on BS3 markup.

    ---
output:
  html_document:
    bootstrap_version: 4
---

    Bootswatch themes

    Regardless of the bootstrap_version, a Bootswatch theme may be added via the theme parameter. When using Bootstrap 4, you can use some new Bootswatch themes (e.g., sketchy, minty, lux, and solar).

    ---
output:
  html_document:
    bootstrap_version: 4
    theme: sketchy
---

    Here’s a list of all Bootswatch 4 themes:

    bootstraplib::bootswatch_themes(4)
    ##  [1] "cerulean"  "cosmo"     "cyborg"    "darkly"    "flatly"    "journal"  
##  [7] "litera"    "lumen"     "lux"       "materia"   "minty"     "pulse"    
## [13] "sandstone" "simplex"   "sketchy"   "slate"     "solar"     "spacelab" 
## [19] "superhero" "united"    "yeti"

    Custom themes

    In rmarkdown documents, you don’t need to create a new theme to start adding to it, because the bootstrap_version and theme parameters are used to create one for you. Thus, to start customizing the styling of a given document, use bs_theme_add_variables() and/or bs_theme_add() inside any R code chunk (see below for more).

    ```{r}
library(bootstraplib)
bs_theme_add_variables(primary = 'salmon')
```

    See the custom themes vignette to learn more.
